THE NEWS.LETTE
Vol. XIV. No. I.

FOOT BALL OUTLOOK.
BRIGHTEST IN YEARS.

\

The football outlook is the brightest we have had in many years and
the odds are much in favor of Captain McCabe leading a team that will
bring home far more victories than
defeats. The new material, that has
come forward to take the places of
the vacancies made by graduation
and other causes, is most of it heavy
in weight and while much of it is
green, still work is rounding it into
fine shape. Moreover old men back
are almost without exception tipping
the scales higher than last season,
and the team will be the heaviest
that ever wore the black and blue.
Thanks to some of the Alumni, the
management has been able to secure
the services of Gill, an ex-Yale star,
who has turned out more than one
winning teani up North. He is a
man who knows football from one
goal post to the other and ably assisted as he is by "Ab" Saylor should
make for us a winning team. Dr.
MacGoffin, who as all know won his
M for football at Michigan, is also
working with the coaches, and three
such heads are bound to bring results.
The team's followers certainly
cannot complain about lack of opportunity for seeing the game for the
Stevens Game is the only away
from Homewood one' on the excellent schedule Manager Merrick has
arranged. It seemed advisable to
drop Delaware and Baltimore Medical College and to take on the
strange teams of Randolph-Macon
and Dickinson. The schedule is indeed an ambitious one, but in spite
of the somewhat discouraging beginning it is quite sure the team will
"come in, strong at the finish" and
add fresh laurels to Hopkins athletics.
The annual struggle to "substitute
something for Physics 1," has now
begun. The class has just finished
the introductory chapter, where we
are told that the earth is round, and
surrounded by atmosphere.
During the summer some changes
have been made in the main library.
The result is a great improvement,
both in appearance and practicability.

BEAT MARYLAND AGGIES
90

Price, 5 cents per copy.

JOHNS HOPKINS
8
RANDOLPH-MACON
0
Our team greatly improved easily
defeats Randolph-Macon. Hopkins
cffence better than ever.
The crowd that braved the.threatening weather last Saturday and
went out to Homewood saw a very
marked improvement in the football
team. The offense tore up the Randolph-Macon line at will and the defence was excellent, save on tricks
and forward passes. An excellent
feature was the help-the-ball-along
spirit,which repeatedly kept the runner on his feet and gaining ground
after he had actually been tackled.
Stollenwerck ran the team with good
judgment and his drop kick was very
prettily placed. Bridgman and Fulton were consistent ground gainners,
while Reed was a tower of strength
in the line.
In the first half Hopkins, by
clung-es through the line, carried the
ball the length of the field and scored a touchdown, but Bridgman failed to kick the goal. During the rest of
the half the ball see-sawed about the
field, Randolph-Macon gainning by
forward passes and Hopkins through
the line. The second half was somewhat similar, and though we got
within striking distance several
times still bad luck prevented scoring save "Stoney's drop. The score

of 8 to 0, does not show the very
marked superiority of our team over
that of the Virginians.

UNIVERSITY NOTES
It is an interesting thing to note
that the men in the entering freshman class range in weight from 87
to 247 pounds.
Freshman: "Where is McCoy
Hall."
Senior: 'A block and a half from
Gordon's."
Owing to pressure of work, Edward B. Clary has resigned his position as captain of the lacrosse team.
Noble Stockett is temporary captain.
Francis' K. Murray, 191o, and
George Harvey Hayne, 1912, are
taking a course at the University of
Maryland.
At a meeting of the Coelon
Club, E. Clary,
was elected chairman, and Stollenwerck secretary and
treasurer. The date of the first dance
has been fixed for December, the
eleventh.

The News-Letter

Y. M. C. A. RECEPTION
-I III
The annual reception given by the
Y. M. C. A., to incoming students
was held on Friday, the eigth. Dr.
Remsen, unfortunately, was forced
to attend the. inauguration of President Lowell, at Harvard. Dr. Griffin made an excellent opening address; it was timely, and well chosen
for the occasion. Dr. Schwartz and
Dr. Steiner also spoke very earnestly, urging the advantage of the Y.
M. C. A. in a university. Mr. Eugene Levering's address was somewhat brief, but thoroughly to the
point; it is difficult to emphaze too
strongly the university's indebtedness to Mr. Levering for Levering
Hall is not only useful, for Y. M. C.
A. purposes, but forms the only room
suitable for general gatherings. McCabe, Stollenwerck and Stockett
made short addresses on university
athletics. The whole ended with the
arranged.
usual collation, which was tastefully

Frey is doing magazine work.

in Charleston.
Hardcastle is in Pittsburg at the
Westinghouse ElectIfic Co.

graduate work here.

THE NEWS.LETTE
Vol. XIV. No. I.

FOOT BALL OUTLOOK.
BRIGHTEST IN YEARS.

\

The football outlook is the brightest we have had in many years and
the odds are much in favor of Captain McCabe leading a team that will
bring home far more victories than
defeats. The new material, that has
come forward to take the places of
the vacancies made by graduation
and other causes, is most of it heavy
in weight and while much of it is
green, still work is rounding it into
fine shape. Moreover old men back
are almost without exception tipping
the scales higher than last season,
and the team will be the heaviest
that ever wore the black and blue.
Thanks to some of the Alumni, the
management has been able to secure
the services of Gill, an ex-Yale star,
who has turned out more than one
winning teani up North. He is a
man who knows football from one
goal post to the other and ably assisted as he is by "Ab" Saylor should
make for us a winning team. Dr.
MacGoffin, who as all know won his
M for football at Michigan, is also
working with the coaches, and three
such heads are bound to bring results.
The team's followers certainly
cannot complain about lack of opportunity for seeing the game for the
Stevens Game is the only away
from Homewood one' on the excellent schedule Manager Merrick has
arranged. It seemed advisable to
drop Delaware and Baltimore Medical College and to take on the
strange teams of Randolph-Macon
and Dickinson. The schedule is indeed an ambitious one, but in spite
of the somewhat discouraging beginning it is quite sure the team will
"come in, strong at the finish" and
add fresh laurels to Hopkins athletics.
The annual struggle to "substitute
something for Physics 1," has now
begun. The class has just finished
the introductory chapter, where we
are told that the earth is round, and
surrounded by atmosphere.
During the summer some changes
have been made in the main library.
The result is a great improvement,
both in appearance and practicability.

BEAT MARYLAND AGGIES
90

Price, 5 cents per copy.

JOHNS HOPKINS
8
RANDOLPH-MACON
0
Our team greatly improved easily
defeats Randolph-Macon. Hopkins
cffence better than ever.
The crowd that braved the.threatening weather last Saturday and
went out to Homewood saw a very
marked improvement in the football
team. The offense tore up the Randolph-Macon line at will and the defence was excellent, save on tricks
and forward passes. An excellent
feature was the help-the-ball-along
spirit,which repeatedly kept the runner on his feet and gaining ground
after he had actually been tackled.
Stollenwerck ran the team with good
judgment and his drop kick was very
prettily placed. Bridgman and Fulton were consistent ground gainners,
while Reed was a tower of strength
in the line.
In the first half Hopkins, by
clung-es through the line, carried the
ball the length of the field and scored a touchdown, but Bridgman failed to kick the goal. During the rest of
the half the ball see-sawed about the
field, Randolph-Macon gainning by
forward passes and Hopkins through
the line. The second half was somewhat similar, and though we got
within striking distance several
times still bad luck prevented scoring save "Stoney's drop. The score

of 8 to 0, does not show the very
marked superiority of our team over
that of the Virginians.

UNIVERSITY NOTES
It is an interesting thing to note
that the men in the entering freshman class range in weight from 87
to 247 pounds.
Freshman: "Where is McCoy
Hall."
Senior: 'A block and a half from
Gordon's."
Owing to pressure of work, Edward B. Clary has resigned his position as captain of the lacrosse team.
Noble Stockett is temporary captain.
Francis' K. Murray, 191o, and
George Harvey Hayne, 1912, are
taking a course at the University of
Maryland.
At a meeting of the Coelon
Club, E. Clary,
was elected chairman, and Stollenwerck secretary and
treasurer. The date of the first dance
has been fixed for December, the
eleventh.

The News-Letter

Y. M. C. A. RECEPTION
-I III
The annual reception given by the
Y. M. C. A., to incoming students
was held on Friday, the eigth. Dr.
Remsen, unfortunately, was forced
to attend the. inauguration of President Lowell, at Harvard. Dr. Griffin made an excellent opening address; it was timely, and well chosen
for the occasion. Dr. Schwartz and
Dr. Steiner also spoke very earnestly, urging the advantage of the Y.
M. C. A. in a university. Mr. Eugene Levering's address was somewhat brief, but thoroughly to the
point; it is difficult to emphaze too
strongly the university's indebtedness to Mr. Levering for Levering
Hall is not only useful, for Y. M. C.
A. purposes, but forms the only room
suitable for general gatherings. McCabe, Stollenwerck and Stockett
made short addresses on university
athletics. The whole ended with the
arranged.
usual collation, which was tastefully
